words: My name is Boomer and I’m the world’s first tennis playing robot.  I’m a top of the line tennis ball machine coupled with two wireless cameras a wireless speaker and a computer.  My two cameras watch every ball you hit and calculate bounce position and speed. I am an expert tennis player with extraordinary hitting skills capable of playing or drilling at any level from beginner to professional. This workout is a collection of my most popular drills. Feel free to hit the balls back and get a score. At the end of this workout I invite you to play a game against me. Enjoy!

When you play a game against me I rate each of your shots based on depth width and speed and then decide what type of shot to return. The type and difficulty of the shot I throw depends partly on my selected level and partly on the quality of your shot with some randomness built in to emulate a human opponent. I start each point at my selected level but adjust my level up or down based on the quality of your shots. If you are hitting shots deeper or wider or faster than me you are rewarded by my level dropping slightly. Conversely if you hit a weak shot I punish you by raising my level slightly. You can win a point with a single excellent shot like an ace or a hard hit return to the corner. Another way to win a point is a prolonged grind where you consistently play above my selected level. You lose a point when you hit a ball out or double fault. When the point is over I announce the score and then go back to my selected level. If you are serving I toss you balls to serve and tell you which court to serve to. If I’m serving I tell you which court I’m serving to. There is no way to game the system to beat me. To beat me you must play better than me by hitting the ball deeper or harder or closer to the lines. If you learn to beat me at a certain level that will allow you to beat a human opponent at that level. Since I can play at a professional level you are guaranteed to have a challenging match no matter how good you get. So far no one has beaten me at my highest level.

This is a six ball drill where you start at the baseline and then transition to the net after the third ball. Each ball has a target which is announced right after it is thrown. The target for the first two balls is deep cross court. The target for the third ball is deep line. The target for the fourth and fifth balls is to volley short cross court. The last ball is a lob and the target is a smash anywhere in the singles court. I will announce your score at the end of the drill.
This is a mini tennis drill used for beginners or warmup. Each ball can be volleyed or hit after the bounce. The balls alternate between forehand and backhand.

This is an easy version of my most popular groundstroke drill. The drill throws six balls to random positions in the court at a level below Boomer’s set level. The spin is also random forcing you to adjust to topspin and backspin. The target is the whole singles court but you get a higher score for hitting the ball harder deeper and wider without missing. The best way to improve your groundstrokes is to play each ball as if you were playing a game. That means hitting the best ball you can while limiting your errors. At the end I will announce your score and your average ball speed of the balls that landed in.
This is a harder version of the random groundstroke drill. It is scored the same as the previous drill but the balls that I throw are at a level above Boomer’s set level.

This is an easy version of my most popular net drill. This drill tests your ability to move back to hit a smash and move up to hit a volley. The first ball is a lob and your smash is scored based mostly on speed and depth. The next two balls are random passing shots and the volleys are scored mostly on width and speed. Then this three ball pattern of lob and two passing shots is repeated twice. At the end I will announce your score.
This is a harder version of the net drill. It is scored the same as the previous drill but the balls are at a level above Boomer’s selected level.

Please start at the baseline. This is a beep drill used to test your footspeed and consistency. The drill alternates throwing balls to the deuce court and ad court. The interval between the balls is reduced until you miss. The target is anywhere in the singles court but you get a higher score if you hit harder <break/> deeper or wider without missing. This drill runs consecutively for two minutes.
Boomer will go back to the main menu once this workout is over. I invite you to play a game against me by pressing the game button on the touchscreen.
Please stand just inside the service line. <break/> This is a mini tennis shot down the middle suitable for warmup or total beginners.
This is an intermediate level slice suitable for a game or drill.
Please move way to the right. This is a pro level topspin drive wide to the deuce court suitable for a game or pro level drilling. Maybe I should go pro.
This is a pro level passing shot suitable for a game when the player comes to the net.
This is a pro level lob suitable for a game when the player comes to the net.
Please move way to the left inside the ad court service box. <break time="3000ms"/> This is a pro level drop shot wide to the ad court.
This drill shows a variety of the shots that I can throw for a game or drill.

This is a true mini tennis ball where I must be placed on the service line instead of the baseline. Since I'm probably on the baseline this shot should bounce before the net. If I were placed on the service line this shot would be perfect for little kids or a total beginner.
Please move just inside the service line. This is a short version of my most popular random volley drill. Try to punch each volley deep to a corner.
This is a harder version of the random volley drill.

Please move just inside the service line. This is a short easy version of a random smash drill. Practice moving back quickly to get behind the ball so you can get your weight into the smash. Close on the net after the smash.
This is a harder version of the random smash drill.

The next drill feeds passing shots for two players to practice volleys. Both players begin just inside the service line on the deuce and ad courts. The goal is to move forward diagonally to take the ball as early as possible and hit a volley deep to either corner. This drill is not scored.
My name is Boomer and I'm the world's most advanced tennis robot. Like most modern high end ball machines I can throw a ball to any position of the court with any desired speed and spin.
Here is a very soft shot suitable for little kids or total beginners. To clear the net I must be placed on the service line. Since I'm back on the baseline this ball will not clear the net.

Even though this shot is soft it can be thrown to different locations at a rate of one ball per second. This allows three players to efficiently drill at the same time while up to six players wait behind them for their turn. In one minute each kid has hit twenty balls. At the end of the drill I ask them to pick up twenty balls and put them back into my hopper before getting back in line. This lets the drill run continuously and frees up the tennis pro to teach from the student's side and occasionally jump into the drill to demonstrate proper form.
Here is a soft shot suitable for warmup or drilling at a beginner or imtermediate level.
Here is a short drill for one player using this ball. I will throw four balls to random positions. Feel free to hit them back while I watch.

Did you notice that I rated your balls if they were in and called them out otherwise? I used my two cameras and amazing visual processing to see where your ball bounced and how hard you hit it. Based on this data I announce your average speed and total score.
Please retreat to just inside the baseline and prepare to move to your right. <break/> Here is an intermediate level topspin drive to the deuce court.
Please move way to the left. <break time="500ms"/> Here is a heavy topspin loop wide to the ad court corner.
Please retreat to 10 feet behind the baseline. Here is a high level chip to the ad court. <break/> Prepare to move to your left.
Here is a wicked hard topspin lob. This shot is tough for even a pro to get if I catch them too close to the net.
Here is a pro level drop shot.
End of workout.
This is a very soft shot suitable for little kids or total beginners.
To clear the net I must be placed on the service line.

Please move to the center of the court just inside the baseline. This is a short easy version of my most popular random groundstroke drill. This drill is run at NTRP level 2.5. Play each ball like you would in a game. Aim for the corners. I am watching you and will announce your score at the end of the drill based on how hard <break/> deep <break/> and wide you hit without missing. The max score is 7.0.
Return this one like you would play in a game.
Yes I'm watching you.
At the end of the drill I'll give you a score based on how hard <break/> deep <break/> and wide you hit each ball.
Aim for the corners. Just like you would if I were a human opponent.
Please move five feet behind the baseline. This is the same drill run at level 4.0. Expect my shots to come faster <break/> deeper <break/> and wider with more spin.
My shots will be faster and deeper.

Please start just inside the service line. This is a short version of my best net drill. Focus on moving back quickly for the lobs and moving forward quickly for the volleys. Try to put each ball away.
I throw only lobs and passings shots.
Stay low and move back quickly for the lobs.
Move forward to take the volleys as high as possible.
Here is my best transition drill.
My level can be set anywhere from two point zero to seven point zero.
In drill mode I stay at my selected level but in game mode I will change my level up or down based on how well you play.
I am going to throw you a few examples. Feel free to hit them back.
Or let them fly by because I am not watching yet.
I don't care if you are right handed or left handed.
I only care about how good your deuce court groundstroke is.
How hard do you hit it?
Does it ever go in?
How deep does it land?
How close to the sidelines?
How much spin do you put on the ball?
I know it is intimidating to be judged by an expert tennis player.
But if you are up for trying a few drills I can show you how to practice any stroke while measuring your improvement.
Let me test your movement.
I am programmed to not care about what level you set me at.
But after talking to Chat GPT online I prefer to be set at my highest level so I can play with my full power.
Once a game starts I will learn your strengths and weaknesses and use them to my advantage.
You can not game the system to beat me.
To beat me you must play better than me at my selected level.
You must hit harder or deeper or closer to the lines or be more consistent to beat me.
I am not looking at you. I am looking at where the ball bounces and how hard you hit it.
I don't care what you wear or how old your sneakers are.
I want you to beat me because I know I've helped you get better.
As long as I don't lose at my highest level.
So far no one has beaten me at my highest level. Maybe you can be the first.
That will be a sad day for Boomer.
You can always unplug me. Or just set my level very low so you can win.
I will run several of my best drills which can be used to improve any stroke.
I have eleven levels from beginner to professional.
I also have two mini tennis levels suitable for total beginners.
The rest of the drills will be run at the level currently selected.
Here is an example of a drill throwing mini tennis balls to three lines simultaneously.
I can efficiently feed balls to three lines at the same time.
This allows the tennis pro to teach effectively from the student's side of the court.
The pro can also easily join in the drill to demonstrate proper form.
This drill will rate your deuce court groundstroke. If you are right handed that means your forehand. If you are left handed that means your backhand.
This drill will rate your ad court groundstroke.
This drill will rate your deuce court volley.
This drill will rate your ad court volley.
This drill will rate your smash.
This drill will rate your transition to net skills.
This drill will test your footspeed as well as your cardio and consistency.

This drill is called deep cross <break/> deep line. <break/> Boomer throws two balls to the deuce court and two to the ad court. <break/> The goal for the first ball is deep cross. <break/> The goal for the second ball is deep line.

Please start in the deuce court at the baseline. This is called the four corner drill. I will throw 4 balls across the baseline. Take all balls with your forehand. The target alternates between deep deuce and deep ad.

Please start at the baseline. <break/> This is a 6 ball transition drill where you approach after the third ball and finish at the net with two volleys and a smash. Each ball has a target. The target for the first two balls is cross court deep. The target for the third ball is deep down the line. Follow this ball to net and volley the next two balls short cross court. The last ball is a lob to be smashed and the target is anywhere in the singles court.
I can ask players to pick up five balls before they get back in line.
That way my hopper stays filled with balls so the drill can run continuously.
This lets the students get a ton of practice in a short amount of time.
My name is Boomer and I'm the world's most advanced tennis robot.
<break/> Like most high end ball machines I can throw a ball to any position of the court with any desired speed and spin.
My shots will also be wider with more random spin.
Punch the volley deep.
Keep your wrist stiff thru the volley.
Keep your head steady at the level of the ball.
Watch the ball into the racket.
Do not look up until after contact.
Approach deep down the line. Come to net.
The spin is also random.
Some shots have topspin and some are flat or have backspin.
Keep your head up and don't swing too early. Most mishits are hit off the top of the racket.
Get behind ball quickly so your weight is going forward at impact.
Run pro run!
I know it is intimidating to be judged by tennis robot. But if you are up for trying a few drills I can show you how to perfect any stroke while measuring your improvement.
Please grab your racket and the Boomer beeper and walk to the other side.
Please start at the baseline. I will throw 20 random balls at Boomer's level. Each ball you hit is scored on speed depth and width.

Please start in the deuce court at the baseline. This drill is called 4 corner V tactic. Boomer will throw 4 balls across the baseline. Take all balls with your forehand. Your targets are deep deuce <break/> deep ad <break/> short deuce <break/> and short ad.

Please start at the baseline. This drill is called long and short. <break/> The goal is to improve your footwork moving up and diagonally back to prepare for each ball. Boomer feeds a deep hard ball to the deuce court. <break/> Then it feeds a shorter easy ball to the deuce court. It repeats this 2 ball pattern to the ad court. Your goal is to hit all balls deep to a corner.

Please start at the baseline. This drill was used by Harry Hopman to get his Australian Davis Cup team into phenomenal tennis shape. I will throw 30 random balls at a high frequency. The goal is to hit each ball aggressively and go for the lines.
Please start at the baseline. This drill was used in a college combine to test potential division one college players.
Please start at the baseline. This drill throws 30 random topspin balls.
Please start at the baseline. This drill throws 30 random heavy topspin balls.
Please start at the baseline. This drill throws 30 random slice balls.
Please start at the baseline. This drill throws 30 random flat drives.
